review.title: The Scope and Limits of Simulation in Cognitive Models
review.abstract: It has been proposed that human physical reasoning consists largely of running "physics engines in the head" in which the future trajectory of the physical system under consideration is computed precisely using accurate scientific theories. In such models, uncertainty and incomplete knowledge is dealt with by sampling probabilistically over the space of possible trajectories ("Monte Carlo simulation"). We argue that such simulation-based models are too weak, in that there are many important aspects of human physical reasoning that cannot be carried out this way, or can only be carried out very inefficiently; and too strong, in that humans make large systematic errors that the models cannot account for. We conclude that simulation-based reasoning makes up at most a small part of a larger system that encompasses a wide range of additional cognitive processes.

sections.heading: 3. Inherent limitations of simulation
sections.text: However one approaches the simulation hypothesis, there is a deeper problem: simulation is simply not as general as it first appears, especially for a layman. It is easy for a layman to overestimate the state of the art in physical simulation and to assume that there is a plug-and-play physics engine that works for pretty much all physical situations. If computer scientists actually knew how to build a comprehensive physics engine, the notion that humans could have an instantiation of something like this seems more plausible, but the reality is that physics engines, as they exist in 2014, are brittle things when it comes to anticipating the full complexity of the real world. Plug-and-play engines only capture narrowly defined environments; more complex applications require hard work by experts. A few seconds of realistic CGI in a disaster movie may require several days of work; an accurate and complex scientific calculation may require several months.

sections.heading: 3.1 Finding an appropriate modeling approach
sections.text: For a programmer building a simulation, the first hurdle to implementing a simulator is the development of a domain model. In some cases, such as pendulums and blocks, this is quite understandable. However, it can often be difficult to find a suitable model, even with familiar objects, materials and physical processes. Consider cutting materials with tools. An ordinary household may have a dozen types of cutting tools: a few types of kitchen knives; more specialized kitchen appliances such as graters and peelers; a few types of scissors; a drill, a saw, a lawnmower, etc. (A specialist such as a carpenter or a surgeon has many more.) Most people understand how they should be used and what would happen if you used the wrong tool for the material; for example, if you tried to cut firewood with scissors. But it would be difficult to find good models for it in physics or engineering literature, where the best minds do not yet have the detailed computer science to solve the situations of engineers.

sections.heading: 3.4 Extra-physical information
sections.text: Suppose you see a baseball pitcher throw a ball. If you simulate the movement of the ball using the best information you can gather about the angle, velocity, etc. of the ball as it leaves the hit zone, and include the inaccuracy of that information, you will predict that it is more likely to land somewhere near the batter. You would achieve better results - by predicting that the ball will land near the hit zone, directly inside or outside the hit zone - by relying instead on the pitcher's known accuracy, plus very specific information about the state of play and the pitcher's willingness to risk a pitcher pitch outside the hit zone, rather than a hit. Pure physical simulation, limited by real-world measurement errors, could yield far less accurate results.

sections.heading: 3.5 Incomplete information
sections.text: Performing a physical simulation is generally only possible if the geometric and physical characteristics of the initial state are precisely known. In many real-world situations, people often carry out physical considerations based on partial, sometimes extremely limited, information. Perception, for example, can be imperfect or incomplete. Knowledge of aspects of the situation can be partially obscured. (An opaque object always closes itself to its own side, far from the viewer.) Knowledge of the physical situation can come from natural language texts or sketches. Knowledge of aspects of the situation can arise from inferences; for example, when someone tries to pick up a suitcase, one can conclude that the suitcase is unusually heavy; one can then use this conclusion for future predictions. Or the exact details are not yet determined.

sections.heading: 3.6 Tasks other than prediction
sections.text: Simulations are most likely to be used in the task of making predictions, such as where a pendulum will be at a given time. However, there are many other important types of physical brainteasers for which simulation-based techniques are generally less well suited, such as: interpolation between two states at two different times; planning; inferring the shape of an object; inferring the physical properties of an object; design and comparative analysis. All of these tasks arise constantly for people in ordinary situations; a cognitive theory of physical thinking must therefore take them all into account.
